column_info.description: Unique identifier (UUID) for the event.
Timestamp when the event message was produced to Kafka.
Timestamp recorded by the event source indicating when the event occurred.
UUID of the product related to the assignment term change.
UUID of the vendor related to the assignment term change.
Nested event metadata including client details and user information; may contain personal data such as user UUID and location.
Internal numeric identifier of the assignment term affected by the change.
Structured event metadata including event UUID, timestamps, client location/device info, experiments, and embedded user info (uuid and roles).
Timestamp of the event occurrence as recorded in the payload.
Unique numeric identifier for the change request.
Identifier or display name of the user who requested the change.
Unique UUID identifying the originating event.
Identifier of the assignment term affected by the change request.
Timestamp when the event was produced to Kafka.
Short code or category representing the reason for the change.
Boolean flag indicating whether the change request was initiated by an internal user or system.
Free-text explanation provided for why the change was requested.
Normalized form of the requester identifier for standardized matching and analysis.
Category or type of the change request (for example, extend or shorten).
Identifier of the product associated with the assignment term.
Timestamp indicating when the status change event occurred.
Nested event metadata containing event identifiers, client information, and user details; may include PII such as user UUID and location.
Unique identifier for the status-change event.
Identifier of the vendor associated with the assignment term.
Timestamp when the event was produced to Kafka.
Numeric identifier of the assignment term whose status changed.
New status value for the assignment term (for example: active, inactive).
Date when metrics were aggregated in YYYY-MM-DD format.
Return on ad spend (ROAS) metric calculated for the ad.
Operational status of the account.
Tracking template applied to the ad's URL for parameter insertion.
Format or type of the ad (e.g., text, responsive).
Click-through rate (clicks divided by impressions).
Final landing page URL optimized for mobile devices.
Average cost incurred per assist action.
Ratio of conversions to clicks for the ad.
Custom tracking parameters associated with the ad.
Operational status of the ad group (e.g., enabled, paused).
Indicator of ad position (top of page versus other positions).
Operational status of the campaign (e.g., active, paused).
Bid match type used for matching bids (e.g., exact, phrase).
Advertising network where the ad was displayed.
Total advertising spend for the ad during the aggregation period.
Identifier for the campaign containing the ad.
Revenue attributed per assist action.
Revenue attributed per conversion.
Unique identifier for the ad.
Number of assist actions contributing to conversions.
Average cost per click for the ad.
Where the ad was shown (for example Search or Content networks).
Match type between the delivered ad and the target (e.g., exact, phrase).
Number of conversions attributed to the ad.
Identifier for the ad group containing the ad.
Identifier for the advertiser account; may identify an individual or business.
Number of times the ad was shown.
Destination URL users land on when clicking the ad.
ISO currency code used for monetary metrics.
Number of clicks the ad received.
Average cost paid for each conversion.
Operating system of the device where the ad was served.
Revenue attributed to the ad's conversions.
Operational status of the ad (e.g., enabled, paused).
Language targeting or detected language for the impression.
Type of device (e.g., mobile, desktop, tablet).
Final landing page URL after any redirects.
URL displayed in the ad creative.
Final app deep link URL used after click-through.
Average revenue attributed to each assist interaction.
ISO 4217 currency code used for monetary metrics in this row.
Total number of times campaign ads were shown.
Channel or placement type where the ad was distributed (e.g., Search, Content).
Operational status of the advertiser account (e.g., active, paused, suspended).
Date representing when metrics were aggregated for this row.
Type of keyword match used for ad delivery (e.g., exact, phrase, broad).
Count of assist interactions that contributed to conversions.
Average cost associated with each assist interaction.
Campaign-level tracking URL template used for click tracking; may contain query parameters.
Operating system of the device where the ad was served.
Return on ad spend (ROAS), indicating revenue generated per unit of spend.
Total number of clicks recorded for the campaign.
Advertising network or channel where the ad appeared (e.g., Search, Display).
Total revenue attributed to the campaign for the reporting period.
Identifier for the advertiser account in Bing Ads.
Unique identifier for the advertising campaign.
Click-through rate: clicks divided by impressions.
Average cost per click for the campaign.
Total advertising spend for the campaign during the reporting period.
Type of device where the ad was displayed (e.g., Desktop, Mobile, Tablet).
Rate of conversions relative to the chosen denominator (commonly clicks).
Number of conversions attributed to the campaign.
Average revenue attributed to each conversion.
Bid match type applied for campaign bidding.
Average cost incurred for each conversion.
Operational status of the campaign (e.g., enabled, paused, deleted).
Placement grouping indicating top-of-page positions versus other placements.
Custom campaign-level parameters used for tracking or reporting.
Identifier for the assignment term related to this contingent change.
Nested metadata containing event context, client_info (location, device), experiments, and user details; may include user identifiers and location fields.
Timestamp when the event was written to Kafka or ingested into the pipeline.
Unique identifier for the event instance.
UUID of the affiliated group or organization associated with the contingent.
Identifier for the contingent entity affected by the change.
Original timestamp when the event occurred.
Device and browser attributes (user agent, screen and viewport dimensions, touch capability, connection type, language).
Content management system metadata including experiment, variant, page and form identifiers.
Unique identifier for the event record.
Timestamp when the event was produced to Kafka or the ingestion system.
Page-level details such as URL, referer, content type, language and product identifiers.
Google Analytics client identifiers (for example _ga and _gid) used for session and client tracking.
Flag indicating whether the event originated from an internal source.
Persistent visitor identifier used to link events to the same user across sessions.
Array of assignment term identifiers associated with the offered service.
Canonical timestamp representing when the event occurred in the system.
Nested metadata including event routing, client_info (location, ja4_fingerprint) and user uuid/roles; may contain personal or sensitive identifiers.
Identifier for the related product request transaction.
Timestamp recorded by the client when the event occurred.
Page metadata including URL, referer, content type, language code and product/reference identifiers.
Timestamp indicating when the event was produced to Kafka.
Boolean flag indicating whether the provider or event is internal to the organization.
Device and client details such as user agent, screen and viewport sizes, touch capability and connection type.
Content management system metadata about experiments, variants and page identifiers.
Timestamp recorded on the client at event creation.
Array of assignment term IDs that were offered to the user.
Persistent or anonymous visitor identifier for the session; may be linkable to a person.
Identifier for the product request associated with the event.
Envelope with enriched event metadata including client info (location, fingerprint) and user sub-structure which may contain user UUIDs.
Unique identifier for this specific event record.
Timestamp when the event occurred.
Array of assignment term IDs that were selected by the user.
Google Analytics identifiers (_ga, _gid) associated with the session; can be used to identify users.
Identifier of the payment instrument used for purchases for this account.
Identifier for the parent customer account, if applicable.
ISO currency code used by the account (e.g., USD).
Identifier for the payment method linked to the account.
Account number assigned by Bing Ads.
Identifier of the customer billed for this account.
Financial status of the account (e.g., billed, delinquent).
Default language setting for the account (e.g., en).
Identifier of the user who last modified the account record.
Timestamp of the last modification to the account (ISO formatted string).
Boolean flag indicating whether the account is archived.
Primary user identifier associated with the account.
Primary account identifier.
Auto-tagging configuration applied to the account.
ETL snapshot timestamp when this record was captured.
Display name of the account used in reporting and UIs.
Lifecycle status of the account (e.g., active, suspended).
Account time zone identifier used for reporting and scheduling.
Numeric code indicating the reason the account is paused.
Template used to construct tracking URLs for clicks.
Bidding scheme or strategy applied to the ad group.
Advertising network where the ad group is served (e.g., Search, Content).
Flag indicating whether ad schedule uses the searcher's time zone.
Array of additional ad group settings, flags, or options.
Language targeting code for the ad group (e.g., en, fr).
Identifier of the account that owns the ad group; may identify the account holder.
Current lifecycle status of the ad group (e.g., Active, Paused).
Start date when the ad group becomes active (ISO or YYYY-MM-DD).
End date when the ad group stops being active (ISO or YYYY-MM-DD).
Privacy or visibility setting for the ad group.
Identifier for the customer associated with the ad group; may identify a person or organization.
Default cost-per-click bid configured for the ad group.
Custom URL parameter key/value pairs used for click tracking.
Suffix appended to final landing page URLs for tracking purposes.
Display name of the ad group.
Unique identifier for the ad group record.
Bid adjustment value applied for audience-targeted bids.
Identifier of the parent campaign that contains this ad group.
Timestamp indicating when this snapshot of the record was created.
Preferred ad format setting for this ad.
Unique identifier for the ad record.
Array of key-value pairs defining custom URL parameter substitutions for tracking.
Editorial review status indicating compliance with platform policies.
Array of final landing page URLs for the ad.
Identifier for the account that owns the ad.
Numeric code indicating device targeting preference (for example, mobile or desktop).
Suffix appended to final URLs for tracking parameters or URL templates.
Template used to generate tracking URLs for clicks on the ad.
Classification or subtype of the ad (e.g., expanded text, responsive).
Array of final app store URLs used for app install creatives.
Operational status of the ad (e.g., enabled, paused, removed).
Identifier of the ad group that contains the ad.
Array of mobile-specific landing page URLs associated with the ad.
Identifier for the campaign that contains the ad.
Timestamp when this ad record was captured or last synchronized.
Identifier for the customer or advertiser associated with the ad.
Display name of the campaign.
Array of campaign-level settings stored as strings (key/value or option names).
Array of campaign type tags or categories (e.g., Search, Shopping).
Current status of the campaign (e.g., Active, Paused, Deleted).
Timestamp when this campaign snapshot was captured.
Type of budget allocation for the campaign (e.g., Daily, Monthly, Shared).
Time zone configured for the campaign (e.g., 'UTC', 'Pacific Standard Time').
Daily budget allocated to the campaign in account currency.
Identifier for the budget object associated with the campaign.
Unique numeric identifier for the campaign.
Bid adjustment integer applied for audience targeting (e.g., percent or flag).
Numeric identifier for the associated advertising account.
Template URL used for tracking clicks and campaign performance.
Bidding strategy or scheme applied to the campaign.
Array of language codes targeted by the campaign.
Numeric identifier for the customer or advertiser account.
Count of CRM service requests recorded for the period.
Number of email open events recorded for the campaign.
Date for which the metrics and targets apply.
Marketing or campaign theme classification used for grouping metrics.
Number of leads converted to sales by CRM in the period.
Targeted net revenue for CRM for the specified date and segment.
Timestamp indicating when this snapshot of the record was captured.
CRM case category or identifier associated with the record.
Top product name or product category driving the reported metrics.
Business area or segment associated with the metrics.
Number of CRM matches (e.g., matched leads or opportunities) during the period.
Number of recipients targeted by CRM email campaigns.
Number of email click events recorded for the campaign.
Program name or title as recorded in Emarsys.
Identifier of the parent program or folder if nested; null for top-level entries.
Current operational status of the program (e.g., active, paused, archived).
Date when the program metadata snapshot was captured.
Unique identifier for the Emarsys automation program.
Boolean flag indicating whether the program has been archived.
Timestamp when the campaign was launched.
Identifier for the Emarsys email template or message associated with this launch.
Unique identifier for the campaign launch record.
Boolean flag indicating whether the campaign launch completed successfully.
Timestamp when this record was captured into the data pipeline.
Flag indicating whether the campaign delivery is scheduled for a later time.
HTML content body or reference used in the campaign email.
Origin system or source name where the campaign record originated.
Template identifier or name used to render the campaign content.
Identifier or name of contact lists excluded from the campaign.
Identifier of the filter used to exclude recipients from the campaign.
Version label or name of the campaign configuration.
Identifier of the administrator or user who created or manages the campaign; may reference internal user IDs.
Flag indicating whether the campaign supports browse-related features.
Identifier or name of the contact list targeted by the campaign.
Flag indicating whether the campaign is a real-time interaction (RTI) campaign.
Numeric or string code representing the campaign status.
Language code used for the campaign content.
Hostname or domain portion of the sender email address.
Unique identifier for the event associated with the campaign.
Display name shown as the sender for the campaign.
Plain text content body or reference used in the campaign email.
Current lifecycle status of the campaign (e.g., draft, active, sent).
Type of campaign (e.g., transactional, promotional).
Content type of the campaign message (e.g., HTML, text).
Primary campaign identifier assigned by Emarsys.
Array of feature flags or attributes enabled for the campaign.
Error message or code returned by the Emarsys API when processing the campaign.
Boolean flag indicating whether attachments are forced for recipients.
Category or classification of the campaign email.
Boolean indicating whether unsubscribe functionality is enabled for the campaign.
Status returned by the Emarsys API for the campaign operation.
Sender email address used for the campaign; may contain personal or contact information.
Email subject line used for the campaign.
Human-readable campaign name.
Timestamp when this snapshot of the campaign record was taken.
Timestamp when the campaign was created.
Filter definition or identifier used to select recipients for the campaign.
Unique user UUID used internally to link contact records across systems.
Date when the contact last transitioned to an inactive status.
Snapshot date indicating when this record was captured.
Emarsys contact identifier used to reference the contact in the source system.
Normalized (lowercased and trimmed) email used for matching and deduplication.
Date when the contact was last reactivated in Emarsys.
Contact's email address.
Unique identifier for the Emarsys program.
Email address or identifier associated with a contact in Emarsys.
Flag indicating whether the program link is archived (true) or active (false).
Human-readable name of the Emarsys program.
Date when this snapshot of the record was taken.
Default currency code used by the account (ISO 4217).
Numeric status code indicating the account state (for example active or disabled).
Boolean flag indicating whether the account is archived.
Display name of the Facebook account or page; may include personal names.
Partner or owner organization associated with the account.
Numeric unique identifier for the Facebook account.
Timezone name associated with the account (e.g., America/Los_Angeles).
Timestamp when this snapshot of account metadata was recorded.
Boolean flag indicating if dynamic creative is enabled for the ad set.
Total lifetime budget for the ad set expressed in euros.
Operational status determined by Facebook after evaluation of the ad set.
Daily budget for the ad set in the account's currency.
Lifetime budget for the ad set in the account's currency.
Manual bid amount set for the ad set in the account's currency unit.
Timestamp of the most recent update to the ad set record.
Remaining budget for the ad set expressed in euros.
Timestamp when this snapshot of ad set metadata was recorded.
Objective used to optimize ad delivery, such as conversions or reach.
Human-readable name assigned to the ad set.
Type of pacing applied to ad delivery (e.g., standard).
Structured details about the promoted object, including pixel_id and custom_event_type.
Identifier of the advertiser account that owns the ad set.
Creation timestamp for the ad set record.
Remaining budget for the ad set in the account's currency.
Scheduled start timestamp for the ad set.
Bidding strategy applied to the ad set (for example, lowest_cost).
Custom event type configured for pixel-based tracking.
Unique identifier for the ad set.
Identifier of the Facebook pixel associated with this ad set.
Current lifecycle status of the ad set (e.g., ACTIVE, PAUSED).
Identifier of the campaign that contains this ad set.
Advertiser-configured status value for the ad set.
Scheduled end timestamp for the ad set.
Daily budget for the ad set expressed in euros.
Original ad set identifier if this ad set was cloned or promoted from another.
Daily budget amount in the campaign's currency.
Lifetime budget normalized to EUR.
ID of the boosted object (post or content) associated with the campaign, when applicable.
Unique identifier for the Facebook campaign.
Special ad category applied to the campaign, if any.
Timestamp when this snapshot of the campaign record was taken into the data lake.
Indicates if automated budget rebalancing is enabled for the campaign.
Buying type for the campaign (e.g., AUCTION or RESERVATION).
Timestamp when the campaign was originally created in Facebook.
Daily budget normalized to EUR.
Array of label objects assigned to the campaign, each containing id and name.
Status explicitly configured on the campaign (e.g., ACTIVE, PAUSED).
Timestamp of the most recent update received from Facebook for the campaign.
Flag indicating whether a spend cap can be applied to the campaign.
Remaining campaign budget normalized to EUR.
Identifier of the Facebook ad account that owns the campaign.
Lifetime budget amount in the campaign's currency.
Pacing strategy for delivery (e.g., standard or accelerated).
ID of a source campaign if this campaign was copied or derived from another.
Campaign name as defined in the Facebook Ads account.
Scheduled or actual start timestamp of the campaign.
Remaining campaign budget in the campaign's original currency.
Scheduled or actual end timestamp of the campaign.
Computed effective status of the campaign considering various settings.
Bidding strategy used for the campaign (e.g., lowest_cost, bid_cap).
Primary campaign objective (e.g., TRAFFIC, CONVERSIONS).
Flag indicating whether a brand lift study can be created for this campaign.
General status value from the source reflecting campaign state.
Unique numeric identifier for the creative.
Headline or title text of the creative.
Structured video payload including video_id, title, message and call-to-action fields.
Structured link payload including link, message, name, caption, description and call-to-action fields.
Identifier of the Facebook Page associated with the creative.
Type of creative object (for example: photo, video, link).
Identifier of the Facebook ad account associated with the creative.
Name label for the creative, often used for identification or grouping.
Main text body of the creative (ad copy).
Domain URL linked in the creative.
Identifier of the Instagram actor or account related to the creative.
Timestamp when this snapshot of the creative was captured.
Customer-specific URL parameters included in ad group URLs for custom tracking.
Numeric identifier of the Google Ads customer (account) that owns the ad group.
Type or subtype of the ad group (for example: standard, dynamic, shopping).
Comma-separated labels or tags applied to the ad group for organization and filtering.
Numeric identifier of the Google Ads campaign that contains the ad group.
Display name of the ad group as defined in Google Ads.
Timestamp indicating when this row was captured or last updated in the snapshot.
Template used to construct tracking URLs for the ad group's creatives.
Unique numeric identifier for the ad group.
Identifier for the bidding strategy applied to the ad group.
Final URL suffix appended to landing page URLs used for tracking parameters.
Serialized ad group settings or configuration such as bidding and targeting options.
Template used to build tracking URLs for the creative's clicks.
Operational state of the ad (for example ENABLED, PAUSED, or REMOVED).
Identifier of the ad group that contains this ad.
Destination URL for the ad click; may include tracking parameters.
Identifier of the Google Ads campaign containing this ad.
Labels or tags assigned to the ad for organization or reporting.
Unique identifier for the ad creative.
Timestamp when the ad record snapshot was taken.
Ad format or type, such as text, image, or video.
The display URL shown in the ad creative.
Numeric Google Ads customer (account) identifier.
Budget amount in base currency units.
Timestamp when this budget snapshot was recorded.
Unique numeric identifier for the Google Ads budget.
Count of references or links associated with this budget.
Current lifecycle status of the budget (e.g., ENABLED, PAUSED, REMOVED).
Human-readable name of the budget as defined in Google Ads.
Method used to deliver the budget (e.g., STANDARD, ACCELERATED).
Budget amount in micros (micro-units of the currency) as reported by Google Ads.
Indicates if the budget is explicitly shared across accounts.
Campaign end date in YYYY-MM-DD format, if set.
Operational status of the campaign, e.g., ENABLED, PAUSED, or REMOVED.
Comma-separated labels or tags applied to the campaign.
Suffix appended to final landing page URLs for tracking query parameters.
Campaign start date in YYYY-MM-DD format.
Name of the budget resource linked to the campaign.
More specific advertising channel subtype, e.g., SEARCH_MOBILE_APP.
Timestamp indicating when this campaign snapshot was recorded.
Optimization status reported by the ad service indicating optimization settings or eligibility.
Google Ads customer account identifier that owns the campaign.
Identifier for the budget resource linked to the campaign.
Unique identifier for the campaign within the Google Ads account.
Human-readable name of the campaign as configured in Google Ads.
Primary advertising channel for the campaign, e.g., SEARCH or DISPLAY.
Template used to build campaign tracking URLs with placeholders for parameters.
Current serving status of the campaign, such as SERVING or NONE.
Identifier of the bidding strategy assigned to the campaign.
Timestamp recording when this row was captured or refreshed in the datalake snapshot.
Numeric Google Ads customer identifier for the managed account; used to link to other Google Ads data.
Tags or labels assigned to the managed customer, usually stored as a comma-separated string or JSON array.
Boolean indicating whether the managed customer account has been archived.
Display name of the managed customer account as shown in Google Ads.
Boolean flag indicating whether this manager account has permission to manage client accounts.
Severity classification of the incident (e.g., low, medium, high).
Current status of the post-mortem (e.g., open, resolved, monitoring).
Timestamp when this snapshot of the record was taken.
Date of the incident or post-mortem record.
Categorized root cause of the incident (e.g., network, code, configuration).
Short title or summary of the post-mortem.
List or description of systems impacted by the incident.
Current status of the partner connection (for example: active, inactive).
Click action configured for campaign-level cookietime.
Mode for click action when optional cookietime is configured.
URL associated with the project or its landing page.
Display title of the commission group.
Numeric identifier representing the channel.
Click action mode for campaign-level cookietime settings.
Campaign-level setting indicating the post-view action behavior.
Click action configured under optional cookietime settings.
Display title or name of the project.
Tracking code associated with the partner connection for attribution.
Timestamp when the connection record was last modified.
Publisher's family name or surname.
Date when this snapshot of the record was captured.
Post-view action mode for campaign-level cookietime settings.
Numeric identifier for the campaign.
Post-view action configured under optional cookietime settings.
Indicator or configuration value for post-view handling.
Display title or name of the channel.
Numeric identifier for the commission group.
Timestamp when the connection record was last inserted into the system.
Mode for post-view action when optional cookietime is configured.
Numeric identifier for the project.
Display title or name of the campaign.
Publisher's given name or first name.
Unique identifier for the publisher.
Total unpaid amount outstanding for the vendor at the time of the snapshot.
Unique UUID that identifies the vendor.
Array of related UUIDs (e.g., invoice or payment record identifiers) linked to the vendor.
Date representing the snapshot day for the payment status.
Timestamp when this record was fetched from the source system.
Vendor debtor/account number used for billing and collections; may identify an account holder.
UUID for the product request associated with the draft service request.
Application product identifier; may be numeric or string.
CMS-related metadata such as experiment, variant, page and form identifiers.
Timestamp recorded by the client when the event occurred.
Unique identifier for this analytics/event record.
Answers submitted in forms; may include personal responses or values that identify individuals.
Timestamp when the event was produced to Kafka or ingested into the pipeline.
Google Analytics identifiers (_ga, _gid) associated with the event.
Contact details captured on the form (email, city, zip, company, comment) and related fields.
Event metadata including client_info (geo/device), event identifiers and user uuid; contains device or user identifiers.
Array of free-text notes attached to the request; may contain arbitrary content.
UUID identifying the product related to the draft request.
List of experiment or feature flags active for the event.
Page-level information including URL, referer, type, language and product reference.
Canonical timestamp for when the event occurred in the system.
Boolean flag indicating if the request was created by internal staff or process.
Marketing and tracking metadata (uids, campaign/ad identifiers, partner IDs) that can include user or lead identifiers.
Identifier for the visitor or session used to link user activity.
Client device information such as user agent, screen dimensions and connection type.
Recorded timestamp of when the subscription change event occurred.
List of triggers or sources that initiated the registration or change.
Structured user information including uuid and roles; contains user identifier data.
Timestamp indicating when consent was revoked, if applicable.
Identifier of the related campaign, if present.
Array of related products with fields uuid, kind, and not_qualified_reason.
Event metadata containing origin, client info and user data; may include identifiers and location information.
Array of target group identifiers affected by the subscription change.
Type of subscription change (e.g., subscribed, unsubscribed, updated).
Current consent details including start time and consent type.
Subscriber's email address.
Timestamp when the event was produced to Kafka.
Unique identifier for the subscription change event.
Customer email address or Emarsys identifier used for contact.
Hour of the event stored as a string for aggregation or partitioning.
Date when the event occurred.
Source or channel where the user registered (e.g., campaign, form).
Title or label of the link associated with the event (e.g., email link text).
Event time component as a string, typically representing time of day.
SHA-256 hash of the customer's email used for pseudonymized matching.
Origin system or channel that generated the event record.
Identifier for the user associated with the record (internal or external ID).
Timestamp when the export trigger was requested.
Customer email address used for Emarsys communications and identification.
Identifier for the specific execution run of the export process.
Numeric identifier of the export job or dataset associated with the trigger.
Number of complaint or spam reports generated by recipients for the launch.
Total number of clicks recorded across all recipients for the launch.
Number of emails successfully handed off for delivery for the launch.
Unique identifier for the specific email launch or campaign.
Recipient email address or identifier associated with the record.
Count of emails that temporarily bounced (soft bounces) for the launch.
Number of emails planned or scheduled to be sent for the launch.
Number of recipients who unsubscribed as a result of the launch.
Count of emails that permanently bounced (hard bounces) for the launch.
Number of distinct recipients who clicked at least once during the launch.
Total number of opens recorded for the launch.
Count of launch events or iterations associated with the email (for example retries or segmented sends).
Count of emails blocked by recipient domains or carriers.
Total number of clicks across all links in the messages.
Number of messages successfully sent to recipients.
Emarsys campaign identifier associated with the launch.
Count of messages blocked from delivery by recipient domains or providers.
Number of opens recorded using privacy-compliant/open-tracking methods.
Number of recipients planned for the launch.
Number of unique recipients who clicked at least one link.
Count of temporary delivery failures (soft bounces).
Number of recipients who marked the message as spam or filed a complaint.
Total number of recorded email opens.
Identifier for the specific launch or send instance.
Count of permanent delivery failures (hard bounces).
Number of recipients who unsubscribed from the mailing list.
Global unique numeric identifier for the merge request record.
Commit SHA of the source branch head for the merge request.
Numeric identifier of the GitLab project that contains the merge request.
Current state of the merge request (e.g., opened, closed, merged).
Boolean flag indicating whether commits were squashed on merge.
SHA of the merge commit created when the merge request was merged.
Timestamp when the merge request was merged; null if not merged.
Timestamp when the merge request was created.
Title of the merge request as provided by the author.
Timestamp of the last update to the merge request record.
Name of the source branch for the merge request.
Internal, project-scoped identifier (IID) for the merge request.
Name of the target branch into which the merge request will be merged.
SHA of the commit produced when the merge request was squashed, if applicable.
Unique numeric identifier for the Bing Ads account.
Identifier of the parent customer account if the account belongs to a hierarchy.
Identifier for the customer responsible for billing.
Primary language or locale code for the account.
Display name of the Bing Ads account.
Type of automatic tagging applied to the account, if any.
Account time zone identifier (e.g., 'Pacific Standard Time').
Account-related number (could represent an account or contact number).
Numeric code indicating why the account was paused.
Three-letter currency code used for billing and reporting (e.g., USD).
Identifier of the primary user associated with the account.
Timestamp string of the most recent modification to the account record.
Lifecycle status of the account such as active, suspended, or closed.
Identifier for the payment instrument associated with the sold-to party.
Identifier of the payment method linked to the account (for example a tokenized payment id).
Financial status of the account (e.g., active, delinquent, suspended).
Boolean flag indicating whether the account is archived.
Identifier of the user who last modified the account record.
Advertising network(s) where the ad group is eligible to serve (e.g., Search, Audience).
End date for the ad group (YYYY-MM-DD).
Template used to build tracking URLs for clicks on ads in this group.
Identifier of the customer (advertiser) owning the ad group; may identify an account owner.
Unique identifier for the ad group record.
Current operational status of the ad group (e.g., Active, Paused).
Default cost-per-click bid amount for the ad group.
Suffix appended to final landing page URLs for tracking.
Start date for the ad group (YYYY-MM-DD).
Flag indicating if ad schedule uses the searchers time zone.
Privacy or consent status related to this ad group.
Identifier for the account associated with the ad group; can link to account-level data.
Human-readable name of the ad group.
Array of additional configuration settings for the ad group.
Bid adjustment value applied for audience-targeted ads.
Primary language targeting for the ad group.
Configuration or JSON describing the bidding strategy for the ad group.
Array of custom key-value parameters appended to URLs for tracking or personalization.
Identifier of the campaign that contains this ad group.
List of final landing page URLs optimized for mobile devices.
Array of app deep links used as final destinations for the ad.
Numeric code indicating device targeting preference for the ad.
Identifier of the customer or advertiser, which may represent an organization or person.
Suffix appended to the final URL for tracking parameters.

Timestamp provided by the client indicating when the event occurred.
UUID of the event used to uniquely identify the recorded event.
Client-side timestamp indicating when the event occurred on the client.
Unique identifier for the event.
Minimum number of DM partners required to validate direct messaging.
Identifier for the related product request.
Total number of partners associated with the questionnaire session.
Identifier for the visitor or user session; may be pseudonymous and can identify an individual.
Timestamp assigned when the event was published to Kafka.
Number of DM partners involved in this session.
Target destination or route the user was redirected to.
Nested metadata containing event, client, and user details; may include location, fingerprint, and user identifiers.
Timestamp when the event was recorded in the system.
ISO 4217 currency code used for the revenue value.
Numeric response code returned by the receiving endpoint (e.g., HTTP status).
Identifier for the processing run or job that produced this record.
Key used to deduplicate incoming events and avoid duplicates.
Identifier of the product associated with the event.
Type of event or action recorded (for example, create or update).
Timestamp when the payload was sent to the external system.
Timestamp when the event occurred.
UUID uniquely identifying the upload inquiry or transaction.
Boolean flag indicating whether the upload job failed.
Partner or vendor identifier code for the source system.
Textual response or error message returned by the receiving endpoint.
Advertising or tracking click identifier associated with the event.
ISO country code representing where the event originated.
Monetary amount reported for the event.
Conversion rate, typically calculated as actions divided by clicks.
Numeric identifier for the advertising campaign.
Total number of clicks recorded for the ad.
Total cost attributed to the ad for the aggregation period in the specified currency.
Click-through rate calculated as clicks divided by impressions.
Cost per click: average cost paid for each click.
Viewable click-through rate calculated as clicks divided by visible impressions.
Total number of times the ad was shown.
Count of conversion actions attributed to the ad (e.g., purchases, sign-ups).
Viewable CPM  cost per thousand viewable impressions.
Numeric identifier for the Taboola account associated with the ad data.
Date for which the performance metrics are reported.
Identifier for the individual ad creative.
Landing page or destination URL associated with the ad.
ISO currency code used for the cost metrics (e.g., USD, EUR).
Alternate or external account identifier used for cross-referencing.
Cost per acquisition: cost divided by number of actions (conversion cost).
Count of impressions considered viewable or visible.
URL pointing to the ad's thumbnail image.
Cost per thousand impressions, cost normalized per 1,000 impressions.
Monetary amount for the order or credited value.
Timestamp of the click event in Berlin timezone.
Hashed representation of the order identifier for pseudonymized linkage.
Short name or alias used to reference the product.
Serialized list of items included in the purchase basket.
Currency code for the source or order amount.
Specific event timestamp converted to Berlin timezone.
Timestamp of the last change to the record in Berlin timezone.
Current processing status of the order or event (e.g., confirmed, cancelled).
Title of the project or product related to the campaign.
Status change timestamp normalized to Berlin timezone.
Timestamp of the click event in UTC.
Date when payout for the transaction is scheduled or executed.
Identifier for the publisher associated with the event.
Identifier for the commission grouping applied to this transaction.
Count of tag codes delivered for this record.
Unique identifier for the order or transaction.
ISO country code associated with the event or user location.
UUID referencing the original inquiry related to the event.
Affiliate or traffic source identifier used for attribution.
External source system entity identifier for cross-referencing.
Identifier for the project tied to the campaign or order.
Identifier of the marketing campaign associated with the event.
Monetary commission amount associated with the transaction.
Monetary amount as reported by the source system.
Event timestamp recorded in UTC.
Identifier for the advertiser associated with the campaign or order.
Timestamp of the most recent change to the record (UTC).
Identifier linking the order to the originating click event.
Origin system or data source for the event.
Publisher's first name, used for contact or reporting.
Free-text description providing additional context for the record.
General event timestamp (system ingestion or event time).
Human-readable title of the campaign.
Reason provided for order cancellation, if applicable.
UTC timestamp when the event was marked as qualified.
Timestamp for the specific action related to this event.
Numeric identifier related to salary or payout records.
Categorization of the transaction event type.
Event timestamp converted to Berlin timezone.
Server-side tracking URL used for tag delivery.
Numeric identifier for the click event recorded by tracking systems.
Searchable title or label for the publisher used in UI and reporting.
Optional sub-identifier for additional segmentation or publisher sub-account.
Type of trigger that generated the event (e.g., conversion, click).
Publisher's last name, used for contact or reporting.
Value associated with the trigger, used for scoring or segmentation.
Identifier for the specific advertisement creative or placement.
HTTP user agent string from the client; can be used for device fingerprinting.
Timestamp when the event was marked as qualified, in Berlin timezone.
Specific event timestamp in UTC representing the original event occurrence.
Title representing the campaign group for aggregation and organization.
Referring URL that redirected the user to the tracked page.
Identifier for the partner or affiliate connected to the transaction.
Timestamp when the order status was last changed.
Timestamp when the order was placed.
Identifier for the product involved in the order or event.
Action performed in the authentication flow (for example 'send' or 'verify').
Type of the resource referenced (for example 'user' or 'device').
Communication channel used for verification delivery (e.g., sms, voice).
Timestamp when the event occurred in the application or service.
Identifier for the verification attempt or code used to correlate attempts; may be sensitive.
Boolean indicating whether Twilio was contacted to send the verification message.
Identifier of the target resource or user account involved in the authentication attempt.
Timestamp when the event was published to Kafka.
Type of contact line used to deliver the code (such as mobile or landline).
Boolean indicating whether the verification attempt was valid/successful.
Globally unique identifier for the event record.
Status of the two-factor operation (e.g., sent, failed, delivered).
Structured event metadata including user details, client_info (location, device) and experiments; may contain PII such as user UUID and location.
Timestamp when the event was recorded in Kafka.
Timestamp when the user action occurred.
Identifier for the related product request.
Nested event metadata including client details, location, device fingerprints, experiments, and a user sub-structure; may contain identifiers and location data.
Unique identifier for the user associated with the event.
Unique identifier for the event record.
Associated value or payload for the labeled event field.
Page-level details such as page URL, referer, content type, language and product context.
Position or index of the element within the page or component.
Categorical label for the event or element used for business classification.
Timestamp recorded by the client when the event occurred.
User identity struct containing uuid and roles; primary user identifier associated with the event.
Boolean flag indicating whether the event originates from an internal user or system.
Identifier of the clicked element on the page.
Ingest timestamp from Kafka indicating when the event was produced.
Vendor-specific metadata such as vendor UUID and modified user role; may contain vendor-linked identifiers.
Section or area of the page where the element is located.
Canonical event timestamp recorded by the ingestion or processing pipeline.

Nested event metadata including event UUID, event time, application, origin, experiments, client_info (geo, device flags, ja4_fingerprint) and user (uuid and roles). Contains user and device identifiers that can be PIIs.
Event type or action name describing the user interaction.
CMS and experiment metadata including experiment and variant IDs, page and form identifiers.
Unique identifier for the event record.
Device details including user agent, screen and viewport dimensions, touch capability, connection type and language.
Client-side visitor identifier (cookie or fingerprint) used to track sessions across visits and considered PII.
Google Analytics identifiers (such as _ga and _gid) associated with the session; considered PII-like tracking identifiers.
Unique identifier for the consent event.
Canonical timestamp indicating when the event was generated or logged.
Device and client details such as user_agent, screen and viewport dimensions, and connection type.
Timestamp recorded by the client when the user action occurred.
Visitor identifier (cookie or device-based id) used to track the visitor across sessions.
Nested event metadata including user identifiers and client_info (may contain location fields like city, postal_code, latitude/longitude).
Struct containing page-level data such as url, referer, language and product context.
Timestamp when the event was ingested from Kafka.
Struct containing user uuid and roles; uuid is a user identifier and is considered PII.
Boolean flag indicating whether the event originated from an internal source.
Array of service consent entries with service_id, name, category, description and consent status.
Content management metadata about experiments, variants and page identifiers.
Identifier assigned to the visitor (device or browser-level id) used for tracking sessions and behavior.
Flag indicating whether the event originated from an internal user or system.
Structured page context including URL, referer, type, language and product or source references.
Rich event metadata including event UUID, origin, client geographic and fingerprint data, and nested user info; may contain personal or sensitive identifiers.
Authentication provider used for the login (e.g., email, Google, SSO).
Timestamp when the event was produced to Kafka.
Timestamp generated by the client when the event occurred.
Unique identifier for the recorded event.
Canonical timestamp for when the event was recorded or normalized.
Structured device information: user agent, screen and viewport dimensions, touch capability, connection type and language.
Indicates whether the user opted to remain logged in.
Structured user information such as user UUID and roles; contains identifiers that can identify an individual.
Google Analytics identifiers (e.g., _ga, _gid) used for tracking; these values can be tied to user sessions or devices.
Analytics visitor identifier that links events to a specific visitor.
Unique identifier for the event message.
Source or type of the registration action (e.g., form_submit, oauth).
Timestamp when the event occurred, as reported in the event payload.
Event metadata containing event identifiers, client geolocation/fingerprint and nested user info.
Google Analytics identifiers (ga and _gid) associated with the visitor.
Timestamp when the event was produced to Kafka or ingested into the pipeline.
Nested user information including uuid and roles; uuid maps to the user identity.
Timestamp captured on the client device at the moment of the event.
Device and browser attributes such as user agent, screen dimensions, connection type, and language.
Page context for the event, including URL, referer, type, language and product identifiers.
Boolean flag indicating whether the registration was initiated by an internal system or user.
CMS and experimentation metadata (experiment/variant/page identifiers and related fields).
Canonical timestamp when the event was recorded in the system.
Free-text notes attached to the event; may contain user-provided or sensitive information.
Unique identifier for the event.
Timestamp when the event was published to Kafka or ingested.
Array of form answers submitted by the visitor, including question and answer identifiers, labels and values.
List of assignment or matching terms associated with the event.
Content management system fields describing experiments, variants and page/form identifiers.
Page-level context such as URL, referrer, language and source.
Status describing the result of the matching process for this event.
Identifier assigned to the visitor for tracking and linking sessions.
Google Analytics identifiers (e.g. _ga, _gid) captured from the visitor's browser.
Nested event metadata including identifiers, client_info (location, fingerprint) and user details.
Device and browser characteristics including user agent, screen and viewport dimensions.
Identifier of the product associated with the event, if applicable.
Tracking and attribution identifiers such as gclid, uid, vendor/ad IDs and campaign metadata.
Timestamp recorded by the client when the event occurred.
Postal code associated with the event or the visitor's location.
Boolean flag indicating whether the event originated from an internal user or environment.
Array of additional answer objects with question id, answers array and insertion timestamp; may contain free-text that can include PII.
Respondent's email address.
Map of metadata key/value pairs attached to the answer.
Type or scale of the score (e.g., nps, rating).
Overall sentiment label derived from the response (e.g., positive, neutral, negative).
Identifier linking the answer to a user (e.g., username or customer id).
Array of property identifiers related to the answer (locations or business units).
Unique identifier for the answer record.
Type of identity provided (e.g., email, anonymous, user_id).
Array of labels or tags associated with the answer.
Timestamp when the answer/event was recorded.
Map of sentiment classifications broken down by label name.
Identifier for the survey this answer belongs to.
Map of label names to arrays of extracted keywords related to each label.
Map of additional question identifiers to their possible answers.
Identifier of the recipient/respondent who received the survey.
Free-text comment from the respondent; may contain personal or sensitive information.
Numeric score provided by the respondent (e.g., NPS or rating).
